title: Long Distance Running Records
content: A retired American long distance runner holds the US record in the half marathon at 59 minutes and 43 seconds. He became the first US runner to break the 1-hour barrier. He also holds the American record in the marathon and is the only American to run sub 2:05, running 2:04:58. He retired in 2016 after a difficult 4-year period, following the London Olympics, which was plagued by lots of injuries.

title: Physical Transformation and Training
content: The runner has transformed his body significantly. He is now into power lifting and carrying out many extreme feats of physical strength. For example, he attempted a 500 lb deadlift and then immediately running into a 5-minute mile. His testosterone is about a 1000 ng/dL, which places him at about the 90th percentile. This is a testament to how he’s changed his nutrition and the fact that he’s not running 110 miles a week.

title: Mindset and Optimism
content: The runner is an incredibly optimistic person. His optimism is what’s allowed him to bounce back from many setbacks.

title: Running at Altitude
content: Many of the best runners in the world come from places that are 7,000 feet altitude, such as Ethiopia and Kenya. Living at high altitude and training at low altitude can be beneficial for distance runners.

title: Cardiovascular Training During Formative Years
content: The benefits of training the cardiovascular system during the formative years are significant. There is a belief that being in an environment that encourages cardiovascular training when you're young, during the formative years of the cardiovascular system, can contribute to the trajectory of one's path. It's suggested that if one doesn’t push their system hard in the teenage years, it’s very hard to develop it later. The effects of cardio at a young age definitely play on later in life.

title: Maintaining Cardiovascular Fitness
content: Even after focusing on strength training and gaining weight, it's possible to maintain a level of cardiovascular fitness. This is especially true for those who developed their cardio early on. Later in life, they just need little touches here and there to maintain their fitness level. Short rests between lifts can be enough to keep in good mile shape without even trying.

title: Altitude and Cardio-Development
content: Kids who are born at altitude have greater potential for cardio-development over time. There are advantages to living high and training low. Today, the answer is crystal clear— best results are attained from living high and training low, when it comes to intensity. It is important to live high and train high for low end aerobic efficiency. But one has to train that anaerobic peak at sea level.

title: Training Techniques
content: Some people sleep in oxygen deprivation tents to replicate living in altitude, so they can train at sea level. This method is used to improve training results. However, trying to push hard in high altitude areas when one lives at sea level can be a waste of time.

title: Training at Altitude vs Sea Level
content: Living high and training low has been found to be effective. Training at altitude is different from training at sea level. At altitude, workouts have to be structured differently, with a lot of intervals to break things up. At sea level, one can spend a lot of time at race pace, working on turnover, which can't be done at altitude without breaking it up more. Going down to sea level for workouts feels good and the results are obvious.

title: Effects of Years Spent at Altitude
content: The number of years someone has spent at altitude also has an effect. For example, someone who is accustomed to altitude can run pretty close to their sea level times at 7,000 feet altitude for a marathon.

title: Marathon Training
content: One of the most important things about marathon training is someone’s threshold. For a 15 mile threshold, one just runs 15 miles at the marathon intensity. If training at altitude, the pace may be slower than at sea level. However, those who are not accustomed to altitude may run much slower at altitude than they would at sea level.

title: Benefits of Living at Altitude
content: Living at altitude can have benefits. Over time, one can get much better at altitude. Going up to higher altitudes can result in a massive jump in fitness. However, the body is always changing and adapting, so one can't repeat the same thing over and over again.

title: Progressive Overload and Switching Up Workout Routine
content: Switching up training is important to see growth. If one is just doing the same lifting all the time and not trying new mechanisms to add weight to the bar, or different tactics, they're not going to see growth. Progressive overload is one of the hardest things to do when one is training themself. The challenge of being able to progressively overload doesn't always mean weight; it can mean sets, reps, reduction in rest time.

title: Blood Flow Restriction Training
content: Recently there has been an obsession with blow flow restriction (BFR training) and weight training; that becomes another way to progressively overload, using a fraction of the weight one would normally use. BFR training is helpful for runners, especially after getting hurt.

title: Recovery from Injury
content: Recovery from injury can be a long process. One individual ended up tweaking the connection to his patella during training, which bothered him all the way up to a major competition. It's important to note that certain exercises may not be beneficial for all types of athletes. For instance, a butt to the ground squat may not be beneficial for distance runners.

title: Importance of Rest and Recovery
content: A break for recovery is important after major competitions. One individual didn't take a big break after running a marathon and ended up feeling flat for the whole build up to the next competition. It's crucial to take a customary break to allow the body to recover.

title: Mental Preparation for Competitions
content: Mental preparation is key for any competition. One has to be ready for any situation that’s going to come and not expect anything. Being in the right state of mind is crucial. If one is not mentally prepared, it can feel like getting hit in the chin with an uppercut, right out of the gate. Competing well in anything is about getting excited while you’re out there. One has to be holding this snowball of excitement as the race is playing out.

title: Mental Health Benefits of Helping Others
content: He felt better from just trying to help other people out. It shifted what was happening inside his mind, inside his heart. Then he was able to find his own rhythm and start to work his way up in that race.

title: Overcoming Injuries in Sports
content: He and Ryan were training together up in Mammoth Lakes and he was dealing with a lot of injury issues going into it. Ryan thinks he had a DNF at the trials that year in 2007; he had some gnarly hip stuff going on. It was actually really cool to see Meb in that situation where he went through so many injuries, so many down times and even mentally struggling with how to handle that and see him pop out at the end of that, win New York, win Boston.

title: Importance of Speed, Power, and Strength for Runners
content: It’s worth pointing out to people listening to this who aren’t familiar with some of these times, just how fast you guys run. For a marathon pace 4:42 to 4:48 [12.5-12.8 mph], these are such insanely fast speeds that the likelihood that a person could run that speed for half a mile, is virtually zero, right? Peter knows right now he could not go out and run 800 meters, half a mile at that pace. Peter used to have a sign in his office, it was a pace clock that said 4:42. Many, many years ago, they had a treadmill set up to that pace [12.76 mph]. The idea was they had random people show up and run, to see how long they could sustain that pace. They would put a harness around a person’s waist and they’d make them run at 4:42. And these people were getting shot off the back of this treadmill after 30 seconds, 40 seconds, one person made it a minute. Right? The reason Peter put this sign up in his office was because he was put off by the notion that people would say, “Hey man, we’re training for a marathon, not a sprint”. He tried to make the point that if someone wants to win a marathon, it feels like sprinting. It’s one thing to go out and run a marathon and take hours to do it. It’s another thing to go out and win a marathon. If someone is trying to win a marathon, they have to understand the pain that these guys are in. They have to understand what 4:42 means; it is insanity. For Ryan, it’s below his threshold, but his threshold is so high.

title: Importance of Speed in Distance Running
content: Distance runners need speed. This is important, distance runners are not slow world class marathoners. One doesn’t have to have that speed while they’re doing marathon training, but they need to have had that speed before that, as a kid growing up. This is what he work on with training— develop the 5K speed, the mile speed first. This is directly correlated to the sprint speed. Develop that first, then grow into the 10K speed, the the half marathon speed, then the marathon speed. When he’s training for a marathon, he’s doing 50 meter sprints twice a week in the middle of marathon training.

title: Strength Training for Power and Speed
content: Strength training for power and speed is crucial. Power is so important for all distance runners. A marathon runner has to have that speed. He knows Meb was doing deadlifts as he was preparing for 2014. He talked to a guy who had overseen part of his strength training program; one of the things he was really fixated on was his strength to weight ratio as measured by a deadlift. A hex bar deadlift with a high concentric and a dropped eccentric. So one picks it up then drops it; pick it up, drop it. The reason for that being the eccentric tears the muscle fibers, and tearing muscle fibers is what’s creating hypertrophy. They didn’t want any hypertrophy; they just wanted the strength.

title: How Strength Factors into Running Form and Speed
content: When someone runs, they have to hit the ground with a toe. The harder one hits the ground, the harder the ground hits them. The harder the ground hits, the higher one goes. The higher one goes, the further their stride. They calculated that for Meb to run the pace he wanted to run in Boston that year, he needed to add 4 inches to his stride. To do that basically required taking his maximal force per unit, body weight from something like 1.3 to 2.7. That was going to translate to 4 more inches of stride. So he didn’t increase his stride rate; he just increased stride length and that was done through strength.

title: Running Technique Insights
content: A runner is putting force into the ground that’s going to shoot them up and out. This is where a runner wants to use their glutes; they are the strongest, biggest muscle. Yet so many runners have very underdeveloped glutes. Hamstrings were probably weak and incredibly tight. These treadmills tell how much force the runner is putting into the ground. How one contacts the ground is so important. A lot of people are rolling through the ground. It’s very difficult to utilize those glutes to really put force into the ground when one is rolling from their heel to their toe. A runner has to contact the ground midfoot and just stomp the ground.

title: Importance of Weight Training for Runners
content: Weight training helps tremendously with that. This is so important for sprinters. The hex bar deadlift – “That’s his favorite lift”. When he coaches runners, that’s the first lift that they do; it’s the most important one. This is one that he’s always trying to increase the amount of load they’re able to handle.

title: Analyzing Running Stride to Improve Speed
content: A device called a G flight measures how high someone can jump and their ground contact time. This has become part of training. It can be used for a static vertical jump, but it would be more interesting for runners to used it for depth jumps. The marker of a great runner is they should have a higher vertical jump when they jump off a box and land and go up than just a static jump. The reason is their ground contact time is way too long and they dissipate too much force. You want to be under 0.28 seconds of ground contact time. This is interesting not because he’s interested in running fast, but because he’s interested in his feet becoming very good at load dissipation and load transfer and force transfer. This is a very important skill as one ages, whether one is walking down a flight of stairs or hiking. But for a runner, if people could get down to a ground contact time of 0.2-0.25 this would increase their speed.

title: Running Techniques and Cooling Down
content: Some people adapt to a certain way of doing things and it might be that they run really well despite that. Experts suggest that fore-foot to toe striking is the way we were meant to run. If one were to look at how our ancestors ran and how force transfer would be most efficient; it’s not striking on the heel. The best runners on the planet don’t cool down. The importance of cooling down was learned in middle school cross country.

title: First Running Experience
content: The first run was around Big Bear Lake, a 15 mile run. It was suffering the whole time. Wearing basketball shoes with no idea what was doing. Legs felt like they just got pounded into a million little pieces halfway through it. Had to stop multiple times, stopped at a liquor store and got a drink, stopped to ice legs.

title: Mental Aspect of Training
content: Running is very nonlinear. The pain felt at 5 miles is a quarter of the distance of 13 miles in terms of effort. The thing about distance running is what’s going on in your head is hugely important. When training athletes, it's important to have a whole bunch of different tactics to manage pain and discomfort. One of the biggest ones that is most helpful is simply turning the mind off. It’s as simple as putting one foot in front of the other as fast as one can.

title: Importance of Being Present
content: The importance of being in the present moment is emphasized. It’s easy to get overwhelmed with the scope of the challenge, especially when trying to do something one has never done before and being in the worst discomfort. That’s what makes people give up and give in. If one can bring themselves back to the present moment of what they’re doing right now; there is always enough to get them through the moment. There’s not always enough to get them through all that’s coming down the line. But if one only tries to do what is in front of them, run the mile they are in and bring themselves to the present moment, there is always enough to get through that moment.

title: Mental Fortitude in Physical Activities
content: Comparing running to swimming— expectations are important in each. One of the things about running that strikes as difficult is you can’t disassociate yourself from the visual cues of how much lies ahead. In contrast, when swimming long distances one had a rule to never look up towards short. They would only know they were near land when they started to see the bottom of the ocean. This requires an extra level of mental fortitude to stay competitive in the race. If you’re going to perform well, you’ve got to be excited about how you’re doing… find something to get excited about in that moment.

title: Reframing Mindset
content: Reframing things in one’s mind is one of the most helpful things one can do. For example, during a challenge, one might think, “what did I get myself into?” The hardest part of the whole challenge for them was just starting back up because they knew what was waiting for them; how far they had to go. But reframing the situation in their mind can help them overcome the challenge.

title: Physical Endurance Challenge
content: Carried 63 lbs in each hand of water up 6.3 miles up a 7% grade, 5,000 feet. It took 6 hours. It was more cardio than strength. He would stop every 50 meters or so to put them down; so it was a lot of carries.

title: Mental Resilience During Physical Challenge
content: Had to reframe a lot. Initially thought it would take him 4 hours to carry these out; his goal was to beat the sun. Found himself getting frustrated about how it was going. Thoughts of, “I’m never going to get out of here” were going through his mind. Had to reframe it and come to peace with what was happening out there and just accept it and then get excited about it.

title: Physical Challenge Completion
content: Once he was able to accept all those negative thoughts and then reframe it, then he was able to embrace this really beautiful experience. This was one that was life changing for him. One that he’ll never forget; getting to the top of that canyon and putting those jugs down. How good it felt to finish.

title: Pace During Physical Challenge
content: It was basically a fast walk. He wanted to make his legs and heart do as much of the work as possible. Just holding that much weight in ones hands becomes an issue.

title: Heart Rate During Physical Challenge
content: This was harder than running a marathon because during a marathon his heart rate is around 167. In this challenge it was probably 195, 197. He has a really low heart rate to begin with. He couldn’t get it over 200. When he was at his fittest, his resting heart rate was 27. Now it is nowhere near that.

title: Comparison to Marathon Running
content: The first 17 or 20 miles of a marathon feel pretty good. He’s conversational. He’s floating along; it’s just fun; he’s enjoying the ride. This challenge was like doing interval training. He was going into his 32nd carry, set it down, take as minimal rest as possible.

title: Physical Exertion and Breathing
content: He would catch is breath and go again. He was breathing super hard when he set it down. This carried on for 6 hours; doing the most intense thing he had ever done before. He was not used to breathing that hard for so long.

title: Hydration and Caloric Intake
content: “The amount of water and calories I was taking in was insane. He was taking in water and then sugar— eating gummy worms like a maniac. He probably took in 3000 calories coming up from the canyon. He was burning so many calories. His metabolism was unreal.

title: Training Consistency
content: The most important part of training is consistency. When he was training for this, most of the time he did 20 minute carries every other day. 20 minutes with 65 lbs in each hand. 20 minutes of— 30 seconds on, 30 seconds off; 30 seconds on, 30 seconds off. He was able to do a 6-hour carry out of the canyon. He trained on flats. It’s easy to be consistent when it’s 20 minutes; he would get home late at night and put on the headlamp. He could be consistent with 20 minutes not with an hour.

title: Importance of Fueling
content: He knows how important fueling is when doing any kind of ultra stuff. He knew if he took in enough calories and stayed hydrated, he was going to be okay in the Grand Canyon challenge. With proper fueling, he could get through anything.

title: Learning from Mistakes
content: Even for modest forms of endurance training, learning the fuel and making dumb mistakes was important. The fuel is important. He knows some athletes who get sick if they eat sugar; the have to use more complex carbohydrates.

title: Deliberate Fueling
content: Ryan was super specific when he was running professionally and those experiences carried over into the farmer-carry Grand Canyon challenge. One can train their gut to take in stuff. Problems arise when one eats new stuff they’re not used to.

title: Carb-Loading Before a Marathon
content: The nutritionist advised to spread the load out so as not to feel bloated and terrible the day before the race. 400 calories of extra carbohydrates would be consumed for 2 days before the race, on top of the carbohydrates normally eaten when training hard. The carbs would be super simple to make it easy on the system. White rice, pasta, and sourdough bread were preferred because of their lower glycemic index and easy digestion. Maltodextrin, a tasteless, liquid calorie, could be mixed with protein powder.

title: Pre-Race Meal and Hydration
content: The pre-race meal was a liquid meal due to waking up really full from all the carb loading done the day before. 3 hours before the race, liquid maltodextrin would be shaken with protein powder, and a little bit of olive oil would be added as a health fat to help slow things down. A gel would be taken right on the starting line and water would be sipped on throughout. Water bottles would be placed on a table every 5K, starting off dilute and getting increasingly concentrated as the race went on.

title: Carb and Caffeine Intake During the Race
content: The body absorbs things more easily when it’s not tired, so it's important to front load carbon intake during the marathon. A gel would be taken at 15K; at 30K, a caffeinated gel would be consumed. Caffeine intake would be timed to where it was taken 75 minutes prior to the start of the race. Caffeine increases one’s core temperature which can be detrimental to endurance activities, but it also boosts performance.

title: Boosting Performance with Tylenol
content: Tylenol is a performance enhancing drug that is perfectly legal. It gives a 1-2% boost, though it’s not clear if this comes through temperature reduction or pain reduction. One needs to be careful with the dose because it’s a very liver toxic drug at high doses, but in normal amounts, 1000 mg is incredibly safe.

title: Viagra and Muscle Performance
content: Research shows that 25-50 mg of Viagra boosts muscle endurance and performance. However, it's a vasodilator and can cause light-headedness in individuals with low blood pressure.

title: Benefits of Deadlifts
content: You would probably see more benefit on your best 10 rep deadlift as opposed to a max deadlift.

title: Effects of Core Temperature on Performance
content: Keeping the core temperature cool can boost performance. Too much or too little temp is pretty bad. If one can keep their temperatures in an optimal range, in theory, it should increase their endurance.

title: Methods of Cooling
content: The best way to lower core temp is through one’s face, the upper face where there is no hair. The next best is through the hands and bottoms of the feet. They developed this glove to dump heat. It’s not icy cold, just cool. One doesn’t want it too cold. It doesn’t change vasodilation. It dumps heat and brings the core temperature down.

title: Use of Cooling Devices
content: Many people invest in a cooling vest; it’s a vest that runs ice water around one’s torso. Using the cooling vest made a difference in how tired he felt after the race. It was the difference between feeling like one was going to die and feeling tired but okay.

title: Incorporating Cooling into Training
content: In interval training, cooling could be done between sets. He’ll use a bucket of cold water at the track for the athletes to put their hands in inbetween sets. It feels like it makes a big difference. He has used those instant cold packs; break them open and hold them for about 2 minutes. It’s kind of a hindrance, but it’s worth it to get the performance benefit.

title: Potential Health Benefits of Cold Gloves
content: The gloves used at Stanford, particularly by the football team and other athletic programs, could have potential applications for running and cycling. The idea of making the handlebars of a bike colder could be beneficial.

title: Struggles and Success in Athletics
content: The early years at Stanford were marked by struggles, particularly in cross-country. However, in the fourth year, things started to click, leading to a feeling of ease and success in running and fitness. This success led to the opportunity to run professionally.

title: Health Challenges During College
content: The first year at Stanford was marked by health challenges, including injuries, sickness, and depression. These struggles led to a temporary departure from Stanford. However, upon return, things gradually started to improve.

title: Achievement of Running a Mile in Under 4 Minutes
content: Running a mile in under 4 minutes is a rare achievement, with only a few individuals, including Jim Ryun and Alan Webb, having accomplished this feat. This achievement was a significant milestone in high school.

title: Training and Work Ethic
content: Alan has such a good work ethic; he would do hurdle drills, pliers, and stuff for hours. Ryan has always been very interested in the nuts and bolts of training. It’s important to understand how he’s doing what he’s doing as an athlete. He has a tendency to try to prove himself to himself in training. He wants to know if he’s fit and ready to go. Sometimes he’s going harder in training than racing. But this isn’t the best way for his body to absorb the work.

title: Mindset and Mental Health
content: In his senior year, his identity was all wrapped up in his performances. This is why he struggled with depression. He would look in the mirror in the morning, he was struggling with running, he was hurt. He was frustrated with how things were going; he wasn’t getting better. Focusing on his faith helped him change his mindset. He started to realize that God loves him regardless of how he performs. He decided to choose to love himself regardless of how he was performing. As that began to sink in, it took the pressure off. He stopped hating himself.

title: Approach to Failure and Teamwork
content: The Africans have this mentality too. They go with the lead group. If they blows up, they don’t take it personally; they get up and go again next time. They don’t take their failures personally. Americans, like Ryan, take it super personally. To fail at a workout is to fail personally. For Africans, to fail is part of the process. Who cares? Just go again. As Ryan’s approach to his workouts changed, thing started to click a lot better. Another big thing he learned is that he didn’t have to beat his work or his teammates in training anymore. Instead, he could just work with them. He didn’t have to try to drop them, even if he could. He became secure in who he was.

title: Importance of Communication in Team Sports
content: Improving communication can help an individual be a better teammate. It’s different to tell the guys that one is feeling really good and is going to pick up the pace than to just take off without saying anything. In a group environment, it’s crucial how just that little communication can really shift the dynamics of the group. It makes everyone cool with what’s happening.

title: Professional Running Career and Discovery of Marathon Potential
content: A professional running career can lead to the discovery of one's gift for marathon distances. However, focusing on speed and shorter distances like the 5K can limit one's upper end potential. After spending a year in college focusing on a 5K and not improving, one might need to figure out their vision for running and what event they would be most competitive at. This could lead to an openness to longer distances.

title: Transition to Marathon Running
content: The path to marathon running can start with experimenting with longer distances. Training for longer distances in the summer and getting into marathon training in the winter can be beneficial. Participating in half marathons and 20K Championships can also be part of the transition. However, it's important to remember that the result of the first race might not be indicative of one's potential in marathon running.

title: Marathon Performance
content: If he was having an A day, he would finish just under the American record pace (60:55). If he was having a B day, he would finish in 61:30. If he was having a C day, he would finish in 62 flat. His training was going phenomenally well. He finished the half marathon at 59:43, obliterating the American record by over a minute. He ran the first mile in 5:35. It felt too easy; he wasn’t supposed to be running that fast. He knows he can hold that effort to the finish. The next mile was 4:32, then 4:28.

title: Physical Sensations During Marathon
content: That day was heaven because he was floating the whole time; it felt easy the entire way. It was the coolest bodily sensation he has ever experienced; it was unreal. He had 1 issue around mile 9 where his stomach got a little bit turny. In a half marathon he’s not taking in any fluids if the weather is cool. It was a nice cool, perfect day day to run in Houston, a flat course. But this feeling passed a couple minutes later. Literally it was easy the entire way.

title: Training and Fitness
content: He was in really good shape. Looking back on it, this is why he is such a big proponent of speed now. He had spent 10 years (from 13-23) working on speed, working on his 5K. Then all the sudden, he piled on marathon training and was hitting longer thresholds and higher volume. This is why he emphasizes 5K speed with the athletes he coaches. The further away I got from that 5K fitness, the harder the half felt, the harder the marathon felt.

title: Athletic Performance and Health
content: He went from a decent track performer to the top 10, all-time performers for a half marathon. He realized he had a chance of medaling in Beijing. There’s a narrow window when one gets to be really good at this; for a runner it’s technically one day. He might be very good for a decade but would look back at this as the best he could ever do. Houston in 2007 was his best half marathon. 4 years later was his best marathon.

title: Aging and Athletic Performance
content: Is being past one’s prime, a retired athlete, a difficult process? Absolutely. Women age better than men in a lot of ways.

title: Mental Health and Athletic Performance
content: He had just been through 4 years of massive struggle. He felt like having a little prayer session with God and sensing a reminder that this is not meant to last forever. So having that moment realization that it’s okay for it to not last forever. He savored it for everything it is worth. This is what he tells his athletes— savor every second of it. But life is going to change.

title: Transitioning Out of Sports
content: Removing one’s self from performance can be super helpful in some ways. When one is in the sport or in transition out of the sport. Realizing the performance is “something that is adding to my life. It is not my life.” Many people talk about having a sense of identity loss when they stop their sport. He had to figure out how to stay true to who he is. Running was just an expression of who he is; it was like his painting. Now he has to find another mechanism to express who he is.

title: Physical Challenges and Mental Health
content: He has moved on to lifting and crazy challenges. He loves physical challenge. He loves seeing growth. He expresses himself now through lifting. And when that comes to an end at some point, he will find another way to express it. He thinks what humans want is having that experience. When one loses the ability to express themself, things can get dark pretty quick.

title: Marathon Training Regimen
content: Ryan’s marathon training regimen at the Mammoth Track Club in 2010 involved intervals on Tuesday, working on 5K-specific speed, things like 6 by mile, 10 by K, 800 meter repeats, 400 meter repeats. He has now gravitated more toward shorter distance repeats— 400s, 200s, things like that. He thinks this is more important for marathoners because one wants a lot of differential between how fast those Tuesday intervals are compared to the Thursday/Friday threshold.

title: Workout Structure
content: On a typical week, Ryan would do an easy 20-minute jog around at an 8 minute mile pace; he would be conversational the whole time, not breathing hard. Then come back and do some dynamic flexibility or maybe some static stuff. There was not a lot of static stretching. Stretching has not been a huge part of his running at all. He wants some tension in his legs. The leg muscles are springs; a tightly wound spring is going to respond to the ground quicker compared to a slinky that’s super slow. He wants a full range of motion so he would do lots of mobility work to get that full range but still keep some tension in the legs. So he would spend 5-10 minutes on drills and strides.

title: Training Experimentation
content: He went through this season experimenting with some new styles of training that he had never done before. New stimulus is always helpful for the body. He had always been in the same routine, doing the same structure training.

title: Race Performance
content: His trajectory was unbelievable, he went from 60th to 10th place. Though he went into this race with the expectation of the running world to earn a medal, 10th place is still impressive.

title: Running Pace and Workout Variations
content: The moderate part would be at 8-minute pace or even faster, 7-minute pace. Then for the fast part, the goal is a 5K pace or slightly slower than a mile pace. There are a lot of different variations that they would take on those workouts.

title: Cool-down and Ice Bathing
content: The cool-down would be 20 minutes. They would spend the rest of the day doing some mobility work, eating, ice bathing. The science on the ice bath has changed quite a bit. They would go from these workouts and long runs straight to the creek, into cold water. Now the science is showing the benefits of having the body to respond to the inflammation first. Now they don’t do a ton of ice baths. But there are a whole bunch of other good, positive effects of ice bathing, like dopamine going up tenfold.

title: Weight Training and Running
content: He would come back in the afternoon for a 30-35 minute easy run then go straight to the weight room and do leg lifts. A mistake he sees a lot of runners make is to do all their leg stressors on the same day. No one feels like doing weights after a hard run. Do the hard run first. Ideally, do the hard run in the morning and come back in the afternoon to do the weights. You can do weights right after a hard run but they probably won’t get as much out of it because you’re bringing fatigue into the lifting. It feels better to space it out a little bit more.

title: Importance of Sleep
content: After a day like this, he would head home to eat and go to bed early. The need for sleep is crucial. He felt like he was sleeping all the time. He would book every day from 1-3 pm for a nap. He would probably sleep 9-10 hours every night.

title: Optimal Body Weight for Competition
content: Optimal body weight for competition and the pros and cons of going below your natural weight. Intense training is hard on the body. They are trying to be as light as possible. Everything comes down to this 1 metric— watts per kilo.

title: Effects of Intense Training on Health
content: Training at that level wasn’t the most healthy lifestyle; it wasn’t optimal for his health. His testosterone level was clinically low every time he tested it— in the 100’s, 150. Ryans testosterone level would come up after a 2-week break.

title: Pros and Cons of Low Body Weight
content: Thinking of weight, his weight got down as low as 127 lbs. He noticed his running got worse if he was less than 137 lbs.

title: Weight Management in Athletes
content: Taking a 2-week break from running resulted in a weight gain of over 10 lbs. This approach was not good emotionally or mentally, but it worked for building up. The problem was getting too lean and light. A healthier approach to weight gain should have been taken. Weight is highly specific for athletes. Trying to get down to weights far from the normal range was unhealthy and resulted in decreased motivation and poor training. It's not healthy to be at a weight that is too low.

title: Training Volume and Intensity
content: Training volume was around 110 miles per week. A common mistake runners make is running at the same pace all the time. To improve, one needs to have super hard days and easy, super chill days. Having variance between pacing is important. This allows one to stress the body, then rest the body. The body will adapt. Most people are training in a zone where it’s too high in intensity to build a true aerobic foundation, and too low in intensity to truly stress the body. Proper training involves being at the more extremes of zone 2 and zone 5.

title: Caffeine and Training
content: Caffeine helps with hard training days. On easy days, the lack of caffeine can make one feel tired. Some athletes really benefit from caffeine. There are different genes that are responsible for caffeine metabolism, so people vary in that.

title: Marathon Training Adjustments
content: One big adjustment was to space things out. He ran intervals on Tuesday and then a long threshold on Friday, with 2 easy days before that. The threshold run is a constant pace, slightly higher than race pace but a shorter distance. The pace approaches race pace as the distance gets longer. He starts out with 5-6 miles and progresses to 15 miles straight, without stopping. He would do 3 of these every week, for 12 weeks building up to the marathon. He would be sure to get 3 of these long thresholds in. They were his biggest indicator workouts.

title: Marathon Training Workouts
content: For this workout, your legs need to little bit of fatigued; you need to be in the middle of hard training. Generally speaking, whatever you can run for that 15 mile threshold, you can hold for a marathon. It’s hard to believe that one can go 11 more miles at this pace, but this is the magic of tapering the energy out on the course, carb loading, etc. That body finds a way to hold that through. That 15 mile threshold of varying distances on Friday, then Sunday comes back with a long run. The long run occurs when there is already a little bit of fatigue in the legs.

title: Marathon Training Mental Preparation
content: A lot of it is just mentally learning how to turn your legs on when you feel really dead, 25 miles into a race. Learning what cues to turn things on and to change gears here. Because it doesn’t matter if you’re running a 6-minute pace or an 8-minute pace, when you get 20 miles into your run, you feel tired. And so you got to just learn what mental cues you can pull on to turn everything on.

title: Marathon Training Formula Tweaks
content: He started spacing things out a little bit more. He would take 2 easy days between every session. He was focused on a 9-10-day cycle. But was making those workouts higher quality, bigger. Sometimes instead of those short Tuesday sessions he would do 20 by 1000 meters with a 200-meter easy job between each 1000 meter. This was done at a faster than marathon pace. The goal is to drive your threshold down. He spent a lot of time running threshold at a certain pace; this was a tad bit quicker and it broken up these threshold runs.

title: Marathon Training Challenges
content: More likely than not, in nearly every build up he would get a little pain. Foot pain, knee pain; little things just pop up. This is usually what would cause him to miss a workout. This is when he would go to cross training. He utilizes cross training more now as a coach than when he was running.

title: Marathon Training and Performance
content: A terrible half marathon performance led to a negative mindset. Despite this, training had been going well and the athlete was in good shape. After the disappointing race, the athlete resumed training and started feeling phenomenal. The training routine involved cycling between training at altitude and sea level. This type of training produces a dramatic increase in hematocrit, hemoglobin, early on in those 1st 3 weeks and then it just starts to taper off. The goal is to keep shifting up. Training at sea level had its benefits such as better sleep and faster running. The athlete started having caffeine every single day and started running his easy runs a lot quicker. The athlete felt like a million bucks going into Boston but had the half marathon performance hanging over him.

title: Effects of Altitude on Training
content: The athlete spent 2 months up at altitude, dropped down to sea level for a month; go back up, drop back down. This type of training produces a dramatic increase in hematocrit, hemoglobin, early on in those 1st 3 weeks and then it just starts to taper off. This goes back down at sea level. But when you go back up to altitude again, it produces another big dramatic shift. The goal is to keep shifting up. There are positives to training at sea level. The athlete sleeps better at sea level, runs faster, and can do workouts at sea level he can’t do at altitude.

title: Preparation for Boston Marathon
content: The athlete started having caffeine every single day; this was the first time in his career he started doing this. He started running his easy runs a lot quicker. Even the day before the race, he did an easy 30-minute run plus 6 x 100 meter strides. He felt like a million bucks going into Boston but had the half marathon performance hanging over him; the feeling of having just tanked.

title: Marathon Running
content: The first half of the Boston Marathon is slightly down, and he had the wind at his back. There is Heartbreak Hill at the very end. From mile 17.5 through mile 20, it’s all up and down hills. It’s known as a challenging, slow course. But again, if you get the right wind and you make the most of it… These aren’t pace races either. In most fast races, there are pacemakers there, and they’re in charge of pace. Guys are just tucked in for most first 20 miles at least, and then they’re off and running the last 10K. In this race he was at the front, just hammering and all of Africa was sitting behind him enjoying the ride. But he didn’t care; he was going to make the most of that day.

title: Physical Endurance
content: Another memorable part of the race was coming through with a mile ago. It was right at two hour. But he’s in the serious pain cave. He went out super fast, super late in the race. No one’s around him and he’s just holding on for dear life. He saw 2 hours flat and was like, “okay, if I break 5 minutes for this last mile, I’m going to be under 2:05”. His PR at the time was 2:06:17. He was already going to run a big PR no matter what. 2:05 was insane; that sounds pretty good. There was a part of him that was like, “just enjoy this last mile, run 5:30; just soak it all in and just enjoy it”. But another part of him thought, “you know what? You might never be here again. Why don’t you just put your head down, grit your teeth and bear it, try to break five and get under 2:05?” And so that’s what he did. And it was a world of pain. That last mile is a blur.

title: Personal Achievement
content: He was in fourth place, but he didn’t even care because his performance shifted away from beating other people, to maximizing his own potential. And that’s what he get most excited about. “It’s about me optimizing what I’ve been given, my gift. And also just seeing the fun part of the growth and the improvement.”

title: Learning from Failure and Performance at the 2012 Olympics
content: Going into the 2012 Olympics in London after Boston, the expectations early in that season were very high. Coming out of a 2:04, he was going to take a shot at winning this race, even though he’d just been beaten by a minute by those guys. He knew he wasn’t expected to necessarily win, but he knew he had a shot. If you run 2:04 for the marathon, in those days, you have a chance to win a gold medal.

title: Importance of Weight Management in Training
content: Talking about not putting on the weight after he ran London, this was a theme going back to Beijing. Leading up to the buildup for Beijing and he did the same thing; and it made his training run flat. This is where having a coach is a helpful thing. If he would’ve told a coach what he was going to do, the coach would say, “That’s a really bad idea. Let’s just stick with what we know works for you in this situation. And that’s putting on 10 pounds.”

title: Effects of Depleting the Body Before Training
content: Preparing for London and lessons learned about not depleting his body. So instead of his weight going from 137 to 150 during that 2-week period, it went from 137 to 130 flat. He started the training in a really depleted state. His body wasn’t in a good state. Mentally and spiritually, he was in the best spot he’d ever been. But his body wasn’t ready to go at all; it needed a break after that.

title: Impact of Calorie Intake on Training
content: When he’s getting stale in training and not seeing growth. If he’s not taking in enough calories; it doesn’t matter how he’s training, it’s not going to work. That’s how it was for him in that buildup, his body was depleted. He didn’t have enough calories on board. It was a frustrating period of training leading up to that.

title: Injury During the London Olympics
content: He’s a very optimistic person, so he’s pretty good at generating hope, and there was some genuine hope at the starting line in London. But early on in the race the pace felt super hard, super fast. This is often the case when he gets too lean and too light; then he has injury issues. But early in the race his right hamstring started hurting, and that’s ultimately what led him to drop out as I was in the middle of that race. He was already starting to limp a little seven miles into the race. He had to be smart, because this is his livelihood, and he’s looking out for the long term.

title: Importance of Physical Health
content: He also wants to be good to his body, and he’s not been good to his body a lot. It was just kind of a moment where he had a sense of clarity that he needed to be good to himself and call it a day.

title: Emotional Health and Coping Mechanisms
content: He tends to go to food when feeling emotionally low. For him he needs this period of just just letting himself be sad for however long that takes, a period of mourning the loss.

title: Belief in Training and Coaching
content: You have to believe that your training is going to work. That’s why it’s so important for athletes to believe in their coach. If you don’t don’t think it’s going to work, it doesn’t matter what’s prescribed, it’s probably not going to work. Belief is so important.

title: Injury and Compensation Issues
content: He had a problem with compensation issues. This is common in runners. He had an issue in his upper high hamstring where it attaches, but he just ran through it. That issue began because he had plantar fasciitis when training for the 2012 Olympic trials. He got that right before the trials, and had no choice but to run through it. Then that persisted for eight months. And so a little compensation resulted in an injury on the other side, in upper hamstring in the games.

title: Nutrition and Health
content: Looking back on it, a big piece of it was nutrition. He got to a better point mentally where he didn’t have to use food binging as a mechanism after bad races. But he still needed to put on weight. Looking back, this is a big part of why he had so many struggles from 2012 through his retirement in 2016. He still needed to get his body in a good spot and wasn’t doing that because he didn’t need to do it from an emotional, mental standpoint. Physically, this was killing him.

title: Importance of Rest and Recovery
content: Taking 3 months completely off from running can be beneficial for the body. A lifestyle shift towards lifting heavy, eating more calories, and getting adequate sleep can restore the body and improve testosterone levels.

title: Benefits of Weight Lifting
content: Weight lifting can contribute to overall physical and mental health. It can be a challenge, but it helps in giving back to the body. It can also offset the depleting effects of running as one gets older.

title: Safe Weight Lifting Practices
content: Being intuitive and cautious in the weight room can prevent injuries. There are healthy ways to lift weights, such as hex bar deadlifts with the handles up and half squats, which are beneficial for runners.

title: Benefits of Blood Flow Restriction (BFR)
content: BFR is a technique that can provide the benefits of lifting heavy without having to put a lot of weight on the bar. It can be particularly beneficial for runners who are skinny or more concerned about getting hurt.

title: Effects of Performance Enhancing Drugs
content: The use of performance enhancing drugs (PEDs) in marathon running is not traditionally common, despite the potential benefits they could provide.

title: Performance Enhancing Drugs in Sports
content: There are athletes who are not on drugs and are winning races. If you can think of one person who’s doing what you want to do and they’re not on it; you’re like, then I can too. There have been guys busted, all over the world. So it does happen occasionally in running. The drugs of choice are EPO, and a lot of gray line stuff too. Where people are just looking for every advantage they can get and maybe crossing some of those lines.

title: Traits of Great Marathon Runners
content: What makes Africans great runners? It’s a perfect storm or highly motivated individuals who are highly genetically gifted. There are some theories about a small pelvis being helpful for distance running. Their body structure gives them a huge advantage. They can run a lot faster than they’re running. A blend of different training approaches might be best.

title: Characteristics of Successful Marathon Runner Kipchoge
content: Kipchoge is genetically gifted but also humble. When you start to think you’re great and done all this great stuff, it almost makes it harder to get back there, or to exceed it. He lives in a super simple place and shares a room with training partners. His mentality and humbleness is inspiring. He balances his fearless mentality with being very controlled in his training. He’s always talking about running like 80% max and everything being super controlled. He’s by far in away the greatest marathoner to ever walk the planet. So whatever he is doing is working.

title: Mental Approach to Training
content: His mental approach to training and racing is the most composed I’ve ever seen in an athlete. What people think is possible now has just been blown up. Now people are trying insane stuff, like a sub-2 hour marathon.

title: Impact of Shoes on Performance
content: With the new technology people are running two minutes faster over the marathon with these shoes on. But I think it’s affected the psyche a ton.

title: Marathon Challenge
content: 7 marathons in 7 days on 7 continents. He started training because if he was going to do this, he wanted to enjoy it. He didn’t enjoy the training. He started getting a lot of the same fatigue issues that came with professional running. So he decided to stop training and enjoy his life for the 9 months leading up to this. He ran 3 days a week, between 5-8 miles. 8 miles was his longest run leading up to this challenge where he was going to run 183 miles in 1 week.

title: Nutrition During Marathon
content: His idea was to take in 50 g of protein every 7 miles or so because he didn’t want to lose his gains. Usually he takes in simple sugar. With this new nutrition by mile 23 he is completely out of it; he needed sugar stat. His protein bar hardly has any carbs in it. At a support tent (which was unmanned) they had laid out dried fruit and candy. He started feeling better immediately.

title: Marathon in Different Climates
content: It starts in Antarctica; this was the coolest marathon. He felt pretty good during the run. The second marathon was in Chile. That marathon felt pretty good. Antarctica was supposed to be really cold, but it didn’t feel that bad. He wore his regular run stuff that he would use in Flagstaff in the wintertime. Full tights, long sleeve, a shell jacket, and gloves/ mittens, and a beanie. He wasn’t sweating at all. They say you don’t want to sweat because it freezes on you and can cause hypothermia.

title: Running in Antarctica
content: Running on the snow doesn’t beat up your legs; it’s a little bit softer. Used the most cushy shoe he could find because he knew his legs were going to take a beating.

title: Running in Miami
content: Had more trouble with this one. Maybe he ran Miami at 3:30 or something.

title: Running in Spain
content: Had the worst day ever in Spain.

title: Running in Morocco
content: Considering how bad he felt in Spain, his goal was to start out super chill and just make it through this one. Started out chill but started feeling good, like his old self. He was mentally super engaged, he started charging, and came home super quick. Ended up running this one around 3:04.

title: Running in Dubai
content: The problem after Morocco was he developed a bit of a limp; his hip was bothering him. Thought he could shake it off. But in Dubai his hip was on fire and he knew something was really wrong. Ended up walking the back half of that marathon.

title: Running in Sydney
content: When they landed in Sydney he tries to stand and put weight on the leg where the hip was bothering him and the pain took his breath away. The pain was super sharp. He knew he was in trouble. He had a hard time putting any weight on it at all. When he got to Sydney his ankles looked like elephant ankles, they were so swollen. It was actually painful. He got a massage in the middle of the run. When he got home and had a MRI he found out he had a stress reaction in his hip. Massages aren’t the best for a stress reaction. It took him 5.5 hours. It was the longest, slowest, most painful marathon. Every time he put his leg down on that concrete he felt the zing of a super sharp pain.

title: Running as a Life-Altering Experience
content: Running has been described as a life-altering experience, providing numerous gifts. It's not just about the physical activity, but also about the people one meets and the shared journey. Regardless of the level at which one runs, the experience is universal when signing up for any race. It's about being out there with thousands of other people who are on the same journey, doing it together.

title: Transition from Running to Coaching
content: The transition from being a runner to a coach can be a beautiful one. The knowledge and experiences gained during the running season are meant to be passed down and shared to help others. Coaching can involve guiding runners of every discipline and level, from super slow people to middle school kids. The goal is not just to improve their running, but also to guide them on their journey and help them live happier lives.

title: Running and Living Happier
content: The ultimate goal of coaching is not just about improving running skills, but also about helping people live happier lives. It's about helping them enter into the good life, finding joy in their journey. Running or lifting can be ways to achieve this, but the primary concern is the athletes' happiness rather than how fast they are.

title: Outdoor Activities and Health
content: Outdoor activities such as hiking, swimming, and running in places like the Grand Canyon can be significant experiences. These activities not only provide physical exercise but also offer a sense of adventure and connection with nature, contributing to overall well-being.
